bestBHT.bht: The power demonstrated in this event is attributed to both the finger of God and the Spirit of God. The finger of God figuratively represents divine power, while the Spirit of God is the living Personal Agent behind that power. It is not necessary to establish a clear distinction between the two, as we have observed even greater variations in similar sayings that are unequivocally the same. The casting out of demons by the finger of God signifies a manifestation of divine power, accomplished effortlessly and unexpectedly, indicating the arrival of the kingdom of God.

Henry Alford: What was done (Hebraistically speaking) by the finger of God, was done by the Spirit of God.
No distinction can be established, as Greswell attempts. The one expression explains the other.
We have much greater variations than this in sayings demonstrably the same.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: the former figuratively denoting the power of God, the latter
the living Personal Agent in every exercise of it.
Marvin Vincent: Is come upon you. See on Matthew 12:28.
Archibald T. Robertson: By the finger of God (εν δακτυλω θεου). In distinction from the Jewish exorcists."
Matthew 12:28 has 'by the Spirit of God.'
The aorist indicative tense here is timeless.
John Gill: The finger is one of the five in the hand, and is that finger which works by the power of Elohim.
John Wesley: If I cast out devils by the finger of God — That is, by a power manifestly Divine.
Perhaps the expression intimates farther, that it was done without any labour.
Then the kingdom of God is come upon you - Unawares, unexpected: so the Greek word implies.

bhtAttempts.bht: The power displayed in the verse is attributed to both the finger of God and the Spirit of God, with one explaining the other. This distinction should not be overanalyzed, as we have seen greater variations in similar sayings. The figurative language of the finger of God signifies God's power, while the Spirit of God represents the living Personal Agent behind that power. The aorist indicative tense used is timeless in nature. This shows that the casting out of demons is a manifestation of divine power, accomplished effortlessly and unexpectedly, signifying the arrival of the kingdom of God upon them.

The power displayed here is attributed to the finger of God, which figuratively represents His power, and the Spirit of God, the living Personal Agent behind that power. We must not read too much into this distinction, as we have seen greater variations in similar sayings that are clearly the same. The casting out of demons by the finger of God signifies a manifestation of divine power, accomplished effortlessly and unexpectedly, indicating the arrival of the kingdom of God upon them.

The power displayed here, attributed to the finger of God and the Spirit of God, signifies a manifestation of divine power in casting out demons. The finger of God represents His power, while the Spirit of God serves as the living Personal Agent behind it. We must not overanalyze the distinction between the two, as there are greater variations in similar sayings that are clearly identical. This act is performed effortlessly and unexpectedly, signifying the arrival of the kingdom of God.

The power exhibited in this event is ascribed to both the finger of God and the Spirit of God. The finger of God symbolizes divine power, while the Spirit of God represents the active personal agent behind this power. It is important not to overly emphasize the distinction between the two expressions, as we have witnessed greater variations in similar sayings that are clearly the same. The casting out of demons is a manifestation of divine power, accomplished effortlessly and unexpectedly, indicating the sudden arrival of the kingdom of God.

The finger of God figuratively represents divine power, while the Spirit of God is the living Personal Agent behind that power. It is not necessary to establish a clear distinction between the two, as we have observed even greater variations in similar sayings that are unequivocally the same. The casting out of demons by the finger of God signifies a manifestation of divine power, accomplished effortlessly and unexpectedly, indicating the arrival of the kingdom of God.
